Discrimination and inequality can hold people back just as much as a lack of legal freedoms. Liberal Democrats have always been champions of liberty and human rights. Liberal Democrats reject this false choice: true security for individuals and for our nation must be built on a platform of equal rights and civil liberties. Discrimination and inequality can hold people back just as much as a lack of legal freedoms. Opportunities are not equally distributed in modern Britain. Where you are from, what your parents did, your ethnicity, health, sexuality and gender still too often affect your chances in life, your educational attainments, your work prospects, how you are treated by the police and the justice system, and even how long you will live. Stopped locking up children of asylum seekers	and strengthened rules on police stop and search. Tackling terrorism and violent extremism Terrorism and violent extremism remain a serious threat to the United Kingdom, which requires a proportionate response. We will: Work with religious and community leaders, civil society groups and social media sites to counter the narratives put forward by extremists, and create the space for the expression of contrary viewpoints and religious interpretations. Maintain laws that provide an effective defence against terrorist activity, including proscription of terrorist groups,	Terrorism Prevention and Investigation Measures, and Temporary Exclusion Orders, which enable the security services to manage the return of those who have fought illegally in foreign conflicts. Ensure efforts to tackle terrorism do not stigmatise or alienate Muslims or any other ethnic or faith group, and that government supports communities to help prevent those at risk of radicalisation from being drawn into illegal activity. Review the process of assessing threats against different ethnic and religious communities to ensure all groups in the UK are properly protected. The UK secures many benefits from immigration, which boosts our economy and helps staff our public services, especially our NHS. But we need to tackle the weaknesses in our immigration system, which threatened to undermine confidence in it. That is why we have led work fully to restore border checks on entry and exit. We need to improve the administration of our system so we deal with asylum claims and visa applications promptly and return those who do not have a valid claim to be in the UK. Then we can start to rebuild an open, tolerant Britain. We will: Complete the restoration of full entry and exit checks at our borders, to rebuild confidence in immigration control, and allow targeting of resources at those who overstay their visas. Speed up the processing of asylum claims, reducing the time genuine refugees have to wait before they can settle into life in the UK and making it easier to remove those who do not have a right to be here. Encourage schools with high numbers of children with English as a second language to host English lessons for parents. And criminals, hackers and terrorists now operate across borders, too. On a domestic level, we see the effects of half a century's liberalisation in a society that has become almost totally dysfunctional: racked by crime; utterly lacking in any sense of community or identity; bereft of moral leadership or moral order; divided, aimless, drifting and - most dangerously - sterile and growing old.

While the British Nation is mature in years, British Nationalism is not. British Nationalism, like its political predecessors in this country, is a response to the conditions and needs of its time. While abroad nationalist movements came into being to fight for national independence or national unity, to safeguard ethnic identity or to reverse the consequences of national defeat in war, in Britain after the Act of Union in 1707 none of the preconditions of a nationalist revolt existed.

On the other hand, the racial homogeneity and character of the British population - only mildly altered by previous settlements of Celt, Saxon, Viking and Norman - became threatened fundamentally by the arrival of immigrants from the West Indies and later the Indian sub-continent, China and Hong Kong, the rapid growth of the communities of these immigrants through further immigration and natural increase, and the policy of enforced multi-racialism which became an article of faith with all the major political parties.

Just as we deplore the divisions that have emerged between the peoples of the constituent lands of the United Kingdom, so do we also deplore the divisions that have been allowed to fester between the peoples of Britain as a whole and their ethnic kinfolk across the oceans, particularly in the Commonwealth. The break-up of the British Empire did not necessitate these divisions, and it is our policy in the future to heal them.

On the cultural front, the need for a movement of nationalism has long been evident. For over half a century, Britain has been swamped by a deluge of trashy popular entertainment, mainly from over the Atlantic, under which our own theatre, film industry and national musical heritage have been largely submerged and in some places virtually destroyed. Government support is clearly needed for the preservation and revitalisation of the traditional folk cultures of the British peoples, particularly in England, where arguably the damage has been most severe.

(2) ETHNIC IDENTITY: Our nationalism is ethnic as well as political - in fact it is ethnic before being political. Britain's ethnic identity, based as it is on a mingling of English, Scottish, Welsh and Irish strains, must be preserved. People of other European strains can be absorbed into our population in limited numbers. Those of non-European origin cannot. It is important to emphasise that this ethnic nationalism is a positive one of devotion to our own race, not a negative of hatred of other races. Every different race has the right of self-preservation, including all the non-white races, and we respect those non-Whites who wish to preserve their ethnic identities as we do ours. [...] (5) THE WIDER BRITISH FAMILY: We recognise the ethnic kinship which exists between the indigenous peoples of the United Kingdom and communities of British origin overseas created by migrations of British people across the oceans. We believe it is important to preserve this kinship and, where possible, strengthen it. (6) BRITAIN'S CULTURE: Government should take on the obligation to preserve the native culture of the British peoples and guard it against incompatible foreign influences.

The traditional industries of the United Kingdom must be protected and where necessary restored. We believe, additionally, that they should be predominantly if not wholly British-owned. This calls for firm controls of imports, as well as regulation of the movement of capital in and out of Britain. The United Kingdom must be held together and separatist movements within its borders strongly opposed. This is not to say that we are hostile to the preservation of the distinct customs and traditions of the constituent lands of the United Kingdom. On the contrary, we seek to strengthen them. We recognise the ethnic kinship which exists between the indigenous peoples of the United Kingdom and communities of British origin overseas created by migrations of British people across the oceans. We believe it is important to preserve this kinship and, where possible, strengthen it.
Government should take on the obligation to preserve the native culture of the British peoples and guard it against incompatible foreign influences.
We have spoken in the previous section of the ties of ethnic kinship that bind British people to peoples overseas descended from British migrants, and of the need to strengthen those ties.

One vital precondition for negotiating preferential terms of entry for British manufactured products with the countries in question would be that our own manufacturing industries must be built up so that they are equal to the highest standards in the industrial world. It would be futile to expect our would-be partners to import junk products at uneconomic prices from us merely out of sentiment and racial loyalty.

We do not think it an exaggeration to say that in this election there is a conspiracy, in which the leaders of all the main parties are culprits, to treat the problems of race and immigration in Britain almost as if they did not exist and were not in any way an election issue. In fact we could claim that we are the only party fighting this election on any significant scale that will deal honestly with race and immigration.

Westminster parlance has given rise to a new expression. It is called ''playing the race card.'' In fact all that ''playing the race card'' really amounts to is recognising that race and immigration are matters of importance in the election and speaking about them frankly and forthrightly. As for 'opportunism', that tendency might more properly be attributed to the many politicians who, seeking the votes of large numbers of ethnic-minority constituents, keep silent on race - except to grovel to the minorities. Nicholas Budgen, the Tory MP for Wolverhampton South West, in an article in the Daily Mail on March 13th, spoke of the frantic efforts of his party's hierarchy to suppress debate on immigration, saying:- As an MP for a constituency with a significant immigrant population, I've asked twice for a debate on the subject in the Commons and have been refused by the Prime Minister and the Leader of the House, Tony Newton. I conclude that some people in politics are embarrassed about discussing immigration for fear of being accused of being racist. Immigration is important to the whole nation. In the past 30 years, large areas of our towns and cities have been transformed by immigration. Schools which were once securely based upon British cultural values have often had to cope with a predominance of immigrant children. In their schools, in their pubs and in their shops, the British have felt like strangers in their own land.

Following the Budgen article, the Tory Party hierarchy, sensitive to the widespread supportive reaction that greeted it, grudgingly consented to individual Tory candidates venturing into the immigration field to the extent of criticising Labour's latest proposals for even further relaxation of immigration rules. A Tory spokesman (unnamed) said, however, that any party candidates who made 'racist comments' in their campaigns would not get any support from the leadership - 'racist comments' meaning of course any frank criticism of the multi-racial society.

Since large-scale non-white immigration into Britain began in the 1950s, a conspiracy of politicians and the news media has contrived to hide the true facts and figures concerning it from the British public. During the 1950s and 1960s, the immigrants were coming in in a flood. Later, the pressure of public opinion forced the politicians at least to adopt token controls. By the 1980s they were telling us that these controls had greatly reduced the numbers coming in. Probably there was some reduction but it was grossly exaggerated, and the numbers still entering were not honestly declared. For the past few years, Tory ministers have been claiming that entrants have numbered about 50,000 a year. Former head of the Immigration Service Peter Tompkins, however - a man who should know something about such matters - exposed this pretence in an article in the Daily Mail (September 22nd 1994) in which he gave the true number as nearer to 120,000. Even this was almost certainly an underestimate, as it assumed a figure of no more than 40,000 illegal immigrants. Other senior immigration officials have calculated that the number of illegals coming in per year could be as many as 150,000! The Government contradicted its own claims just a few months later when in March 1995 a message from Environment Secretary John Gummer to London borough councils warned council officials to make housing plans to accommodate a million new immigrants over the next 15 years. That amounts to nearly 67,000 a year coming into London alone! These government estimates do not allow for the expected influx of an unknown number of Chinese due to settle in Britain after this year's scheduled handover of Hong Kong to Communist China. Prime Minister Major has in fact made a statement to the effect that up to 5 million Hong Kong Chinese would have the legal right to come here and live. Though there is no question of the whole of this number coming, even as few as one tenth of them would add a further half million in a short time to the numbers entering. As far as the total numbers of the ethnic minority population are concerned, governments over the past 30-40 years have again been less than honest with the British public. Currently, a figure of about three million is being touted around as the probable aggregate. This figure, like other official ones however, is grossly misleading. Official statistics for many years relied for figures of black and Asian people upon a count of those born in the West Indies and the Indian sub-continent or to parents born in those areas of the world. The figures constantly disregarded ethnic minority members born to parents who were themselves born in Britain. This latter figure must now be enormous. Just occasionally, and inadvertently, the truth slips out. Such an occasion was a report in the Daily Star (20.2.93), which said that: ''A telephone directory listing the numbers of Britain's 7 million-strong (our emphasis) ethnic minority community was launched by the Government yesterday...'' This we reported in the BNP monthly paper British Nationalist, with the comment that it was not certain whether the figure referred to the ethnic minority population as a whole or merely that part of it living in homes where there were telephones! A call by an unannounced BNP member to the publishers of the directory, known as Black Pages, eventually extracted the admission that the figure of 7 million was somewhere near correct. The official figure, the spokesman said, was far short of the true one because two out of every three 'ethnic' families declined to fill in population census forms. Even assuming that the figure was not an underestimate (as it may have been), the probable current rate of entry of 'legals' and 'illegals' would by now have brought the number up to nearer 8 million! Mr. Budgen's description of the transformation of our towns and cities through immigration, taken together with our own observations as we travel about Britain, makes this latter figure seem far closer to reality than those repeatedly passed off on us by officialdom. We in the BNP have always believed that the open-door immigration policy initiated by governments in the early post-war years, and only slightly modified during the past two decades, has been a grave error. In fact, its consequences have been disastrous.

Mr. Budgen has spoken of the British people feeling like strangers in their own land. As people of wholly disparate races have been forced to live side-by-side in confined spaces, there has been tension - sometimes exploding into large-scale rioting. Prime Minister Major, in a speech in January of this year clearly pitched at the ethnic minority vote, tried to tell the British public that these riots were a thing of the past - which begs the question of whether he was on a trip to outer space when his own one-time home town of Brixton went up in flames barely more than a year previously! And there is one thing which cannot be gainsaid where these riots are concerned. Almost all of them, and all of the really big ones, have been staged by ethnic minority groups, mainly against the police; nothing on such a scale has been initiated by white people, who generally have shown tremendous restraint in the face of the tensions brought on by the breakdown of the multi-racial experiment. In our section dealing with education, we have spoken of the aggravation of already existing problems by the presence of large ethnic minority communities in many areas: the great difficulties experienced by many Afro-Caribbean children in adapting to school discipline; the vast cultural divide, exacerbated by religious differences, separating Asian school pupils from white British ones; the consequent overloading of the school curricula with additional subjects designed to cope with these problems - Asian languages for Whites, English for Asians, Islamic Studies, 'anti-racism' courses, courses to familiarise diverse schoolchildren with each other's cultures, and so on ad nauseam. It is not true, as some of the BNP's opponents have claimed, that we blame the ethnic minorities for unemployment. Nevertheless, it is true that in certain areas of employment Whites have suffered a lowering of job expectations as a result of the ethnic minority presence in Britain. This has been aggravated by the policy adopted by employers in the public sector, and enthusiastically encouraged by governments, of 'positive discrimination', whereby ethnic minority members are hired according to a quota system which takes no account of qualification or merit, and results often in better qualified white applicants being rejected for the jobs in question. High unemployment would certainly exist without the ethnic minorities being present in Britain, but their presence here, equally certainly, has made it worse for our own indigenous British people. But beyond all this, there is another development fraught with alarming consequences for Britain's future. The growth of the ethnic minority communities, and their concentration in particular urban areas, is resulting in the growing power of the 'ethnic vote'. It has already been acknowledged in a number of newspaper articles over the past year or two that this vote in a number of marginal constituencies could be high enough to determine the result of an election. In a closely fought contest (whether or not the coming election turns out to be one such), the ethnic minority vote could in fact decide who wins and forms the next government. The Tory, Labour and Liberal Democrat parties are keenly aware of this and are falling over themselves to curry favour with the ethnic minorities. This is the future of Britain that we are looking at: the ethnic minorities, though still just that - minorities, could hold the balance of power in this country and thereby have the politicians eating out of their hands and bowing to almost any demand they may care to make. In the case of many such politicians, this is evident already; in the future it will only get worse. That is, unless the indigenous British people close ranks and take action - soon - to ensure they retain control of their country! Whatever the immediate problems and tensions caused by immigration - the main ones of which we have highlighted in the foregoing paragraphs - these pale into insignificance compared with the long-term consequences for Britain of continued non-white immigrant influx, the relatively higher ethnic minority birthrate and the inevitable intermingling and intermarriage that will increase as the ethnic minority population increases as a portion of the whole: there will be a drastic change in the British population, with the eventual result that the British Nation will become something wholly different, racially and culturally, to what it has been over the past centuries of magnificent British achievement. Britain will in fact become less and less a white European country and more and more a Third World country. In the United States, where the process of non-white immigration, a prolific non-white birthrate, widespread inter-racial marriage and the raising of mixed-race children has been going on much longer and on a comparatively greater scale, it is predicted that the white peoples, whose ancestors built the country, will become a minority by around 2050. By the middle of the next century the Americans could lose their country. By the end of it, if not before, we could lose ours! By 'we', we mean of course the Anglo-Saxon and Celtic peoples whose unique blend of Northern European stocks gave Britain her greatness and her genius. Do we want this to happen? Certainly, powerful and influential people in politics and the mass media want it to happen and are doing their best to speed up the process by a ceaseless onslaught of propaganda in support of multi-racialism. We don't believe, however, that the majority of the British people - deep down in their hearts - want it to happen. The desire that the future generations of our nation look like us, think like us and have our aptitudes and qualities is as basic to human nature as the desire that our own children, grandchildren and great grandchildren should do so. The promotors of the multi-racial society, in order to intimidate those who might disagree with them, have brought a new term into the vocabulary: 'racist'. By 'racist', they mean of course anyone who recognises the inherent biological differences between races and wishes to preserve his own race. We will not oblige these perverters of the language by using their terms. What we very definitely do admit to being is racial patriots who value our own racial heritage and want to maintain it intact. This has nothing to do with 'hating' other races - a pursuit which we believe is stupid and wrong. This, then, is the essence of the immigration and race issue. In importance it towers above all else. We see the position of Britain today as that of a country whose frontiers are imperilled by the threat of invasion, an invasion which will take our country away from us for ever if we do not resist it. We in the BNP are the leaders of that resistance, and it is in this role more than in any other that we appeal to the British people in this election to support and follow us. We do not see the ethnic minorities themselves as `enemies'; they are merely victims of a vast conspiracy and racket hatched by the political classes and aided and abetted by the mass media, just as we are. We wish them no ill; indeed we are only too ready to collaborate with them to bring about a painless solution to the problem - those of them who realise, as more and more do, that that solution is as essential for their own good as it is for ours. The BNP has been in contact with some members of ethnic minority groups with a view to helping them obtain assistance in getting repatriated to their ancestral homelands. Last year, some of our members even took part in a small demonstration in support of repatriation side by side with members of the ethnic minorities. Out of these small beginnings, we are confident that bigger things will come. This whole issue is not a matter of 'hate'. It is a matter of the mutual survival of our race and others, each in its own territory, each with its own identity, each to its own way of life. The horrifying future that awaits Britain as a result of the follies of Third World immigration can only be averted if we adopt two very firm policies:- Future immigration of non-Whites must be stopped. Non-Whites already here must be repatriated or otherwise resettled overseas and Britain made once again a white country. We have spoken here of 'non-Whites' because immigration is, as we have said, a racial problem. There is not any great problem created by the moderate number of white people from overseas who have settled here; nearly all of these can be, and mostly have been, peacefully integrated into the British population without friction and without any noticeable racial change in the national stock, or negative impact on our European culture. Contrary to the claims of our political opponents, and of those who champion immigration and multi-racialism, a ban on immigration on racial grounds is neither impossible nor objectionable. The Japanese operate a virtual ban of this kind, and our politicians have not screamed in protest against it. Israel operates a strict curb on non-Jews entering that country. In past times, most white countries effectively prevented, by one device or another, non-Whites settling within their borders. The United States prohibited non-white immigration while carefully segregating the non-Whites already within its borders. The 'White Australia' policy existed up till only a few decades ago. Few challenged the right of any such country to determine, at its own discretion, the kind of new settlers it would accept, if any. The United States and Australia are very large, spacious countries, with the latter still containing a relatively small population. Britain, by contrast, was already densely populated and crowded before the first non-white immigrant waves began to arrive just after the Second World War. The need for us to control immigraton is a matter of simple common sense. It is equally sensible that, among the immigrants we do accept, we should be entitled to discriminate on racial grounds. BNP policy with regard to immigration is simple and straightforward. We place applicants to settle here in three basic categories:- Those who can prove wholly white and predominantly British ancestry and are of sound health and good character should be allowed to settle here as they please. Those of wholly white but not British ancestry should have their applications to settle here treated each on its individual merit, but in most cases should be accepted, provided the same rules of health and character are observed. In the event of any very large movement of populations of this kind into the United Kingdom, this policy would of course have to be reviewed. At the moment, however, there is no evidence of such a danger. Wholly or partially non-white applicants to settle in Britain would be refused except in cases where they can provide evidence of some strong occupational necessity to reside in this country, such as membership of some diplomatic corps or positions as representatives of foreign countries trading in the UK. In these cases they would be regarded as temporary residents, with no rights of British citizenship. The vast majority of so-called 'refugees' pouring into Britain every year are not real refugees at all but simply people seeking to better their living standards. Of course, most of them have stories of 'persecution' back home that are well rehearsed in readiness for tugging at the heart-strings of the many 'liberals' and 'do-gooders' they expect, not without good reason, to have waiting to welcome them when they get to this country. Governments, in the face of pressure from public opinion, have in recent years gone through the motions of trying to ascertain whether the 'refugee' claims are genuine before granting these people right of settlement, but this whole process has been farcical: as the claims are being investigated, the self-styled 'refugees' disappear into the interior of the country and are mostly never seen again; they end up by staying here as illegal immigrants. In just a few cases they are caught, and this enables our rulers to make a few token expulsions, carried out with a view to appeasing the angry public and buying a few indigenous white votes. The procedure of investigation of 'refugee' claims, together with the job of attempting (mostly in vain) to track down the bogus claimants is, needless to say, a big drain on the public purse. A BNP Government would vastly simplify this whole process. It would not matter to us whether 'refugee' claims were genuine or not; we would make the decision as to whom to admit to this country on the basis of whether the claimants in question were the kind of people we wished to welcome here and integrate into our population. Non-Whites of all categories would not be admitted; Whites, as stated before, would have their cases examined individually and these cases would be treated on merit. In the cases of such Whites, an important question would be that of what they were refugees from. Some of them might well have been experiencing troubles in their countries of origin for quite justified reasons. We would not want such people transferring their dubious activities to Britain. Resettlement of Britain's ethnic minorities overseas would begin on a voluntary basis, with generous inducements given to all concerned to leave Britain of their own free will. Our extensive programme of aid to the Third World, at present granted mostly without strings, would be used as a leverage to persuade the recipient countries to accept quotas of immigrants from the United Kingdom. Such migration should be arranged so that, as far as possible, those leaving these shores will go to their countries of origin or the countries of origin of their parents or grandparents. Aid to these countries will be tied to the financing of jobs and housing for the coming settlers as well as extra schools for their children, but with something over in the way of general economic assistance. Air or boat fares of the settlers would be paid by the British Government, and settlers would, in addition, be given resettlement grants to provide them with an extra reserve when they arrive at their destinations. From the moment of the introduction of this voluntary resettlement scheme, it would be made clear to the ethnic-minority members that it was the first part of a two-part programme of resettlement, the second part of which would be organised on a compulsory basis. In the second, compulsory, part of the programme of resettlement, fares would be paid and aid given but the latter would be considerably less generous. This would constitute an obvious inducement to those affected to avail themselves of the voluntary resettlement scheme. A time limit would be set for applications for resettlement under this scheme, after which those failing to apply would be subjected to compulsory resettlement when their time came. What we can say, however, is that all those affected by the programme would be given fair time to wind up their affairs in this country and find housing, employment and, where necessary, schooling in the countries of their destination. To assist in all this, housing, employment and educational agencies would be set up with offices in the United Kingdom which would be at the service of all those seeking help in these fields. The arrangement would be not dissimilar to the scheme under which large numbers of British people were enabled to emigrate to Australia in the years shortly following World War II. Equally impractical would be an estimate, right at this stage, of the financial cost of the operation, including of course the level of resettlement grants given to those involved. There can be no doubt that, at the least, it would be a very considerable cost indeed. Such a cost, however, would have to be set against money saved in a great many sectors in which immigration and multi-racialism are now a burden on the British economy: the extra cost of education in a multi-racial and multi-cultural society; the cost, up and down the country, of special facilities and services provided by local authorities to cater for ethnic-minority communities' needs; the considerable cost of dealing with the 'refugee' problem; the huge expense of maintaining the bloated 'race relations' industry, with its many wings and its lavishly paid army of professional busybodies, snoopers, agitators and brainwashing specialists; the damage done to private and public property in areas affected by rioting; the additional costs of law-enforcement. The list is endless. Even when these savings are taken into account, there can be no doubt that the resettlement programme which we are advocating here will still represent a large claim on the public purse for the 10-20 years it will probably take to complete. The way that we must see this expenditure is as an investment in Britain's long-term future: in communal harmony and peace; in higher educational standards; in greater economic efficiency; most important of all, in the recovery and preservation of our national identity as a people. At times of a threat to national survival in war, we have never questioned the need to spend large sums of the nation's money on the needs of defence and fighting capability - as much as it has taken, in fact, for us to win through. Today there is a threat to our national survival no less in gravity than those confronting us in the past when great foreign armies faced us across the channel. We must pay what it costs to deal with that threat, for the alternative is national extinction. There is one further thing that should be said about a programme for the overseas resettlement of Britain's ethnic minority population, and it is something that should taken carefully to heart by 'liberals' in this country who are always lecturing us on our duty to the Third World. This is that Third World countries are in fact desperately crying out for the skills which have been learned in Britain by immigrants and their descendants. It is surely not unreasonable to propose that those skills would be best employed helping to improve life for everyone in the countries in which these people would settle, whereas here in Britain they only duplicate skills that are already adequately supplied by the indigenous population. There must be a ban on all further non-white immigration into the United Kingdom. A two-part programme must be organised for the resettlement overseas of non-Whites presently in the UK. The first part should be voluntary, the second compulsory. After the expiry of a time limit for applicants for voluntary resettlement, those remaining should be subject to compulsory resettlement. All those subject to resettlement should have their travelling expenses to their destinations paid by the British Government -- plus an additional resettlement grant. However, the grant should be more generous in the case of those applying for resettlement under the voluntary part of the programme. In modern Europe, Britain effectively invented human rights. The EU's Charter of Fundamental Human Rights, that Britain has just signed, is a document of a fundamentally different kind, and it resembles more closely the constitution of the old Soviet Union.Â  Its aim, we are told, is to 'give Europe a soul' or prove that the EU is more than purely an economic machine. But the human rights under the Charter can be defined by the state and they take precedence over individual freedom. Freedom of speech and publication, freedom of religious organisations and freedom of private association are all at risk. Taken to its logical conclusion, the EU's 'anti-discrimination' policy as reflected in the Charter means that a Christian school could be forced to employ atheist teachers, or a Muslim organisation to appoint Christian managers. The perverse effect of this will be to emphasise differences between sections of society and give power to self-appointed activists. The European Union favours divisive 'group' rights over individual freedom. Only outside the EU will Britain be a truly inclusive society. At the same time, the UKIP regards the protection of citizens from crime as one of the principal duties of government. UKIP would not pay benefits to foreign nationals resident in the UK until they have paid tax for 5 years. Mass uncontrolled immigration has been extremely damaging to Britain. We have open borders with the EU but successive British governments have also failed to control immigration from outside of the EU. UKIP will introduce a selective and limited Australian style points-based immigration system. Immigration for permanent settlement must be strictly limited. UKIP will develop the UK Border Force into a Migration Control Department directly responsible to a Minister. This department will oversee the immigration system and border control. Migrants will not be able to claim public housing or benefits until they have been a tax paying resident in UK for a continuous five years. Workers on permits and students will be expected to possess private health insurance as a condition of entry to the UK (unless covered by a reciprocal medical treatment agreement). UKIP will rescind the UK’s assent to the Barcelona Declaration (1995) and the Marrakesh Declaration (2018). Both of these documents pave the way for yet more uncontrolled and unlimited immigration from Africa, the Middle East and beyond. Rich foreigners will try to find loopholes no doubt, and government will have to try and close them. Veterans would be prime candidates for jobs in the new Migration Control Department designed to control immigration Around 11% of the prison population are foreign nationals – over 9,000. UKIP would seek to deport foreign criminals, and where possible to have agreements with foreign states whereby we pay them so that their citizens can serve their sentences in their own countries. It would be cheaper, and might also act as something of a deterrent. Such criminals would be have a life-time ban on re-entry to the UK. The most significant threat to the Green Belt, and the UK environment in general, especially in England, is unsustainable population growth, which is predominantly fuelled by mass uncontrolled immigration. UK laws to protect children must be implemented fully and impartially, irrespective of the culture, ethnicity or religious beliefs of the perpetrators. UKIP will repeal the law allowing exemptions for ritual non-stun slaughter. Islamic Extremism: The worst excesses of a literalist interpretation of Islamic doctrine has seen unprecedented acts of terrorism in Britain and across the world. This can only be countered with practical measures. UKIP will legislate to ban the overseas funding of mosques and imams. A large proportion of UK mosques are funded from countries such as Qatar, Saudi Arabia and Pakistan, who export their extremist ideology to the UK. UKIP will end mass uncontrolled immigration, and under a security-based screening policy we restrict any limited migration from Islamic countries to those people we can be sure, as far as possible, do not follow a literalist and extremist interpretation of Islam. Islamic extremism is actively fostered in HM Prisons at state expense. Islamic gangs hold sway in some prisons and non-Islamic prisoners are converting for their own protection. UKIP would introduce the separation of prisoners or prisons exclusively for Islamic prisoners who promote extremism or try to convert non-Islamic prisoners. UKIP would repeal the legislation that gives legal recognition for Sharia law courts. Islamic extremism is an on-going problem that will take generations to resolve, and effective policy ideas will have to be developed whoever is in power. wishes to embrace that identity should do so, whatever their ethnic origins may be. English identity resides in the heart and mind not on the skin. For example, it allowed the BBC to advertise BAME (Black Asian Minority Ethnic) only internships and training schemes – thereby discriminating against white youngsters. Our people should be treated equally under the same laws.

Immigration has enriched our nation over the years and we want to attract the brightest and the best people who can make a real difference to our economic growth. But immigration today is too high and needs to be reduced. We do not need to attract people to do jobs that could be carried out by British citizens, given the right training and support. So we will take steps to take net migration back to the levels of the 1990s “ tens of thousands a year, not hundreds of thousands.
Setting an annual limit on the number of non-EU economic migrants admitted into the UK to live and work;
limiting access only to those who will bring the most value to the British economy; and,
applying transitional controls as a matter of course in the future for all new EU member States.

In addition, we will promote integration into British society, as we believe that everyone coming to this country must be ready to embrace our core values and become a part of their local community. So there will be an English language test for anyone coming here to get married.

We want to encourage students to come to our universities and colleges, but our student visa system has become the biggest weakness in our border controls. A Conservative government will strengthen the system of granting student visas so that it is less open to abuse. We want to make it easier for reputable universities and colleges to accept applications, while putting extra scrutiny on new institutions looking to accept foreign students or existing institutions not registered with Companies house. In addition, we will:
insist foreign students at new or unregistered institutions pay a bond in order to study in this country, to be repaid after the student has left the country at the end of their studies;
ensure foreign students can prove that they have the financial means to support themselves in the UK; and,
require that students must usually leave the country and reapply if they want to switch to another course or apply for a work permit.

Extremists, serious criminals and others find our borders far too easy to penetrate. That is why we will create a dedicated Border Police Force, as part of a refocused Serious Organised Crime Agency, to enhance national security, improve immigration controls, and crack down on the trafficking of people, weapons and drugs. We will work with police forces to strengthen arrangements to deal with serious crime and other cross-boundary policing challenges, and extend collaboration between forces to deliver better value for money.

Under Labour, the number of foreign criminals in our prisons has more than doubled. We will extend early deportation of foreign national prisoners to reduce further the pressure on our prison population.

We will scrap ID cards, the National Identity Register and the Contactpoint database. To protect our freedoms from state encroachment and encourage greater social responsibility, we will replace the Human Rights Act with a UK Bill of Rights. We will review and reform libel laws to protect freedom of speech, reduce costs and discourage libel tourism.

Terrorism remains a major threat to our country and some of the biggest threats to our security do not come from abroad they are home grown. A Conservative government will ban any organisations which advocate hate or the violent overthrow of our society, such as Hizb-ut-Tahrir, and close down organisations which attempt to fund terrorism from the UK.

Our approach to foreign affairs is based on a belief in freedom, human rights and democracy. We are sceptical about grand utopian schemes to remake the world. We will work patiently with the grain of other societies, but we will always support liberal values because they provide the foundations for stability and prosperity.

Protecting Britain's enlightened national interest requires global engagement. We will be safer if our values are strongly upheld and widely respected in the world. Our national identity is bound up in our historic global role as an outward-looking nation, giving generously to developing countries, and providing a safe haven to genuine refugees.
A Conservative government will always speak up for freedom and human rights. Torture is unacceptable and abhorrent, and we will never condone it.

To ensure that the British people retain their homeland and identity, we call for an immediate halt to all further non-white immigration, the immediate deportation of criminal and illegal immigrants, and the introduction of a system of voluntary resettlement whereby those non-white immigrants who are legally here will be encouraged, but not compelled, to return to their lands of ethnic origin. The BNP will ensure the proper financial and material provisions are available for this, with the aim of halting and reversing the trend towards a non-white Britain, and ensuring that the British people have a homeland and retain their unique identity.
The BNP calls for the selective exclusion of foreign made goods from British markets and the reduction of foreign imports.

We deplore the degree to which Britain's industry, commerce, land and other assets have been allowed to fall into the hands of foreign owners. We are pledged to ensure that all vital national assets are restored to British ownership. We also call for preference in the job market to be given to native Britons.

We are wholly committed to a free, fully funded National Health Service for all British citizens. We will see to it that no money is given in foreign aid while our own hospitals are short of beds and the staff to run them.

We reject the idea that Britain must forever be obliged to subsidise the incompetence and corruption of Third World states by supplying them with financial aid. If aid is given, it must be in return for certain services. The billions of pounds saved every year by this policy could be reallocated to vital services in Britain, including improvement to the Health Service and greater care of our old folk.
We will restore national service for our young, for the purposes both of boosting our defence capability and of giving them a sound training in citizenship.

Britain's foreign relations should be determined by the protection of our own national interest and not by our like or dislike of other nations' internal politics. We would have no quarrel with any nation that does not threaten British interests. We will maintain an independent foreign policy of our own, and not a spineless subservience to that of the USA, or any other country.

This manifesto illustrates how withdrawal from the EU can benefit the UK right across the spectrum, from immigration to crime, tax, jobs and the economy, pensions, public services, and even through to animal welfare and Post Offices.

As a member of the EU, Britain has lost control of her borders. Some 2.5 million immigrants have arrived since 1997 and up to one million economic migrants live here illegally. Former New Labour staff maintain that this policy has been a deliberate attempt to water down the British identity and buy votes. EU and human rights legislation means we cannot even expel foreign criminals if they come from another EU country. This is why immigration control is so essential and overdue. UKIP will:
· End mass, uncontrolled immigration. UKIP calls for an immediate five-year freeze on
immigration for permanent settlement. We aspire to ensuring any future immigration does not exceed 50,000 people p.a.

· Regain control of UK borders. This can only be done by leaving the European Union. Entry for work will be on a time-limited work permit only. Entry for non-work related purposes (e.g. holiday or study) will be on a temporary visa. Overstaying will be a criminal offence

· Ensure all EU citizens who came to Britain after 1 January 2004 are treated in the same way as citizens from other countries (unless entitled to ‘Permanent Leave to Remain’). Non- UK citizens travelling to or from the UK will have their entry and exit recorded. To enforce this, the number of UK Borders Agency staff engaged in controlling immigration will be tripled to 30,000
· Ensure that after the five-year freeze, any
future immigration for permanent settlement will be on a strictly controlled, points-based system similar to Australia, Canada and New Zealand

· Return people found to be living illegally in the UK to their country of origin. There can be no question of an amnesty for illegal immigrants. Such amnesties merely encourage further illegal immigration
· Require those living in the UK under
‘Permanent Leave to Remain’ to abide by a legally binding ‘Undertaking of Residence’
ensuring they respect our laws or face
deportation. Such citizens will not be eligible for

benefits. People applying for British citizenship will have to have completed a period of not less then five years as a resident on ‘Permanent Leave to Remain’. New citizens should pass a citizenship test and sign a ‘Declaration of British
Citizenship’ promising to uphold Britain’s
democratic and tolerant way of life
· Enforce the existing terms of the 1951 UN Convention on Refugees until Britain replaces it with an Asylum Act. To avoid disappearances, asylum seekers will be held in secure and
humane centres until applications are
processed, with limited right to appeal. Existing asylum seekers who have had their application refused will be required to leave the country, along with any dependants

Require all travellers to the UK to obtain a visa from a British Embassy or High Commission, except where visa waivers have been agreed with other countries. All non-work permit visa entrants to the UK will be required to take out adequate health insurance (except where reciprocal arrangements exist). Those without insurance will be refused entry. Certain visas, such as student visas, will require face- to-face interviews, and UKIP will crack down on bogus educational establishments

· Repeal the 1998 Human Rights Act and withdraw from the European Convention on Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms. In future the British courts will not be allowed to appeal to any international treaty or convention that overrides or sets aside the provisions of any statue passed by the UK Parliament
· Reintroduce The ‘Primary Purpose Rule’
(abolished by the Labour Government),
whereby those marrying or seeking to marry a British citizen will have to convince the admitting officer that marriage, not residence, is their primary purpose in seeking to enter the UK
· End the active promotion of the doctrine of multiculturalism by local and national government and all publicly funded bodies
